title: How to Repair Electric Car Windows

steps.title: Locate and open the fuse box.
steps.content: Locate and open the fuse box. It should be located inside the car as a part of, or near, the dash.

steps.title: Check your owner's manual to locate that operates the windows.
steps.content: Check your owner's manual to locate that operates the windows. It is not uncommon that the only thing wrong with electrical components in a vehicle is a blown fuse. If this is the case with your windows you will need to replace the window fuse. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Pull the fuse straight out of its cradle.
steps.content: Pull the fuse straight out of its cradle. Be careful not to twist or otherwise force it. You do not want to damage the cradle or break a piece of the fuse off in the cradle. There are fuse tongs available at part supply stores that can help with this.

steps.title: Locate a replacement fuse.
steps.content: Locate a replacement fuse. It must be the rated for the same amperage as the original fuse that operated the window mechanism. The amp rating should be printed on the fuse, and it should also be listed in your owner’s manual. Do not use a fuse with a higher amp rating, as this may lead damaging the electrical components of your vehicle.

steps.title: Push the new fuse straight down into the cradle.
steps.content: Push the new fuse straight down into the cradle. The fuse must be “set”. This means that it does not move or wobble.

steps.title: Turn your car key to the "on" position.
steps.content: Turn your car key to the "on" position. This provides power to your windows and allows you to test them. You need not start your car.

steps.title: Test your windows.
steps.content: Test your windows. Confirm that they go up and down without restriction.

steps.title: Evaluate the condition of your window seals and gaskets.
steps.content: Evaluate the condition of your window seals and gaskets. You want your gaskets and seals in good repair. They are responsible for keeping rain out by forming a water tight boundary when your window is rolled up. They also serve to insulate the inside of the vehicle from road noise.

steps.title: Check the entire gasket channel for foreign objects.
steps.content: Check the entire gasket channel for foreign objects. Any obstruction of the channel may prevent the window from rising or falling properly. You should remove any objects such as pebbles or leaves before proceeding.

steps.title: Clean the gasket with acetone.
steps.content: Clean the gasket with acetone. This will help to remove any grease or dirt build up that might impede your window or prevent your gaskets from sealing properly. Be very careful not to get any acetone on your car's paint or carpets. It's better to put a small amount on a cloth and wipe with the cloth than to pour the acetone directly on the gasket.

steps.title: Repair any small tears.
steps.content: Repair any small tears. You can do this using a rubber adhesive or glue. Be sure to trim any loose corners with a razor blade so that you get a good seal.

steps.title: Replace the gasket.
steps.content: Replace the gasket. This may be necessary if the original gasket has large tears or several small tears. Replacing the gasket is a fairly easy job. Use a trim removal tool to slide in between the window and the gasket. Hook the tool underneath the gasket and pull up. Once the old gasket is removed, install the new gasket by fitting it into the same place as the original and pushing down firmly.

steps.title: Lubricate the channel with silicone spray.
steps.content: Lubricate the channel with silicone spray. This will help your window glide smoothly along the channel.

steps.title: Retest the window.
steps.content: Retest the window. Your window should move up and down without restriction or delay if the problem has been fixed.

steps.title: Find an electrical schematic of your vehicle.
steps.content: Find an electrical schematic of your vehicle. This can be found either from information in your owner's manual or on the Internet.

steps.title: Trace the wiring from the fuse panel to the switch.
steps.content: Trace the wiring from the fuse panel to the switch. You should refer to your electrical schematic for help. You want to make sure that there are no breaks in the connection from the fuse box to the switch. If you did not find a schematic, it might be easier to trace the wiring from the switch back to the fuse box to look for any breaks in the connection.

steps.title: Use a multi-meter to confirm that the switch is getting 12V of power.
steps.content: Use a multi-meter to confirm that the switch is getting 12V of power. Attach the leads of the multi-meter to where the electrical wires come into the switch and set the meter to D/C volts. It should read 12 volts.

steps.title: Trace the wiring from the switch to the motor.
steps.content: Trace the wiring from the switch to the motor. This is the path that a signal will travel to move your window when you press the switch. Any breaks or loose connections in this path will prevent your motor from functioning properly.

steps.title: Use the multi-meter to confirm that the motor is getting 12V of power.
steps.content: Use the multi-meter to confirm that the motor is getting 12V of power. Attach the leads of the multi-meter to where the electrical wires come into the motor. Again, set it to D/C volts and it should read 12 volts.

steps.title: Look for any interrupted voltage caused by a loose connector or corrosion.
steps.content: Look for any interrupted voltage caused by a loose connector or corrosion. If there are any loose or corroded connections in the circuit they will disrupt the signal and cause your window to malfunction.

steps.title: Fix the connector or corroded areas.
steps.content: Fix the connector or corroded areas. Push any connectors or wiring harnesses together tightly, and clean any corrosion away with a wire brush or similar tool. .

steps.title: Test the window again.
steps.content: Test the window again. If your problem was in the circuitry and is now fixed, then your window should freely roll up and down without any restrictions or delays.

steps.title: Locate the window switch panel.
steps.content: Locate the window switch panel. This is the button used to operate your window. It is almost always on the door, however, they are rarely found on the center console.

steps.title: Remove the window switch panel.
steps.content: Remove the window switch panel. Be careful not to scratch up the door panel while removing the window switch, as it often requires prying. Using a shop rag or piece of cardboard under your prying tool can help.

steps.title: Unplug the wiring connectors from the switch.
steps.content: Unplug the wiring connectors from the switch. You will need to test these connectors to make sure that they are providing the appropriate 12 volts to your switch.

steps.title: Use your multi-meter to probe each connector.
steps.content: Use your multi-meter to probe each connector. Set the multi-meter for D/C volts and put the prongs of your multi-meter into the connector. It should read 12 volts.

steps.title: Check the wiring on any switch that has a low voltage reading.
steps.content: Check the wiring on any switch that has a low voltage reading. Tighten any loose connections, and clear away any corrosion.

steps.title: Test another switch.
steps.content: Test another switch. Take a switch from another door and plug it into the connectors on the malfunctioning door. If you are able to operate your window using this switch, then the original is bad and will need to be replaced.

steps.title: Buy a new switch.
steps.content: Buy a new switch. Contact your dealership or favorite parts store and get a new window switch.

steps.title: Install the new window switch.
steps.content: Install the new window switch. This can be done by plugging the connectors into the switch and popping the switch back into the door panel.

steps.title: Remove the door panel.
steps.content: Remove the door panel. This task will vary from car to car, but typically you will have to remove some screws around the middle of the panel (such as inside the door pull) and then use a prying tool around the outside to pop out the clips on the perimeter. [2] X Research source Sometimes you may have to remove things such as weather-stripping or door moldings as well.

steps.title: Use a multi-meter to make sure that the motor is getting the correct voltage.
steps.content: Use a multi-meter to make sure that the motor is getting the correct voltage. Attach the probes of your multi-meter to the motor’s plug and toggle the switch up and down. [3] X Research source Make note of the voltage in both directions. Your owner’s manual should list the specific voltage required.

steps.title: Ensure that the window moves freely during this test.
steps.content: Ensure that the window moves freely during this test. There should be no slow spots or blockages.

steps.title: Unplug the motor.
steps.content: Unplug the motor. If you the motor is getting the proper voltage but not functioning properly, you likely need to replace it. Start by unplugging the wiring connectors from the motor. If your motor is functioning properly but the window is not responding, you may need to replace your regulator.

steps.title: Remove the bolts that attach the regulator to the glass.
steps.content: Remove the bolts that attach the regulator to the glass. The regulator is the lift assembly that moves your window up and down. You will have to move the window up or down to align these bolts with a hole in the door interior. Using an extension on a ratchet, you will put a socket (usually 8 or 10 mm) through the hole and loosen the two bolts.

steps.title: Push the window all the way up.
steps.content: Push the window all the way up. Use your hands to push the window up, and then either fasten it with tape or pull it out of the door altogether.

steps.title: Unplug the wiring harness from the window motor.
steps.content: Unplug the wiring harness from the window motor. You will have to press down on the clip that holds the wiring harness into place and pull the harness out. These can be hard to press and sometimes it is best if you can get a screwdriver on it to press it in.

steps.title: Unbolt the harness and/or motor from the door's interior.
steps.content: Unbolt the harness and/or motor from the door's interior. Any bolts holding the harness and motor will have to be removed. These can often be difficult to bolts to remove. You may need to use a ratchet with a long extension to provide the necessary angle to access and turn the bolts.

steps.title: Pull the motor and harness out as one assembly.
steps.content: Pull the motor and harness out as one assembly. Once you have the assembly removed, you can separate the two pieces and replace the one that is malfunctioning.

steps.title: Re-install the motor/regulator assembly.
steps.content: Re-install the motor/regulator assembly. Once you have replaced the malfunctioning part, whether it was the motor or the regulator, it is time to slide the assembly back into the door's interior and bolt it back into it's original position.

steps.title: Plug up the new motor.
steps.content: Plug up the new motor. Plug the wiring harness into the window motor. This will provide power to the motor so use caution.

steps.title: Lower your window back into its correct place on the wiring harness.
steps.content: Lower your window back into its correct place on the wiring harness. Remove the tape or re-install your window. Make sure that the tabs in the bottom of the window are properly aligned to bolt it back onto the regulator.

steps.title: Bolt the window to the regulator.
steps.content: Bolt the window to the regulator. Using the bolts you removed earlier and the same extension, you need to bolt your window back to the regulator.

steps.title: Test your window.
steps.content: Test your window. It should now move up and down freely when you press the switch.
